block.p: As if home archivists don't already have enough to do, TeraOptix's Terapin audio and video CD recorder has put another intriguing road on the entertainment map.
The Terapin is a sleek device that can write 74 minutes' worth of video with audio (or audio alone) onto blank CD's.
As if home archivists don't already have enough to do, TeraOptix's Terapin audio and video CD recorder has put another intriguing road on the entertainment map.
The Terapin is a sleek device that can write 74 minutes' worth of video with audio (or audio alone) onto blank CD's.

Promoted, for the moment, as the first consumer digital video recorder, the Terapin, which sells for $499, is not a CD-R drive, so it does not require a computer to function. With the Terapin, you plug in your TV, camcorder, VCR or audio component of choice, then compress the content into MPEG files that can be visually edited, indexed and searched on CD.
Your production can be played on the machine itself or on a DVD or VCD player or a multimedia computer.
The advantage is, of ourse, that your home movies will last longer on a CD than they will on tape.

Critics have pointed out two weaknesses of the Terapin: first, its videos can be blurry, like old Blockbuster rentals. Second, while undeniably easy on the eyes, the curvature of the Terapin's top thwarts its ''stackability'' -- a trait that may not matter so much once your VCR and CD player are collecting dust in the basement.
